Award.AwardTitle: Focus on Retention in Cohorts of Engineering Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The College of Engineering at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) will implement FORCES (Focus On Retention in Cohorts of Engineering Students) to create two cohorts each with 21 engineering students supported by scholarships in their freshman and sophomore years. FORCES cohort students will take classes together and a peer counselor-taught class covering academic skills and engineering topics. Additionally, the FORCES program will provide student support academic activities during all semesters. The FORCES cohort program will be open to all incoming freshman engineering majors with financial need who have acceptable admission credentials and test ready for Pre-Calculus I; emphasis will be placed on recruiting students historically underrepresented in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The College of Engineering at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) has implemented FORCES (Focus On Retention in Cohorts of Engineering Students) since Summer 2009 to support cohorts of engineering students with scholarships and academic services in their freshman and sophomore years. FORCES cohort students take a number of classes together, which includes a peer counselor-taught class covering academic skills and engineering topics.

Attrition in engineering majors at UTA and elsewhere occurs largely in the first two years. FORCES seeks to retain engineering students through these years by ensuring they use peer mentoring, participate in study groups, attend selected extra-curricular activities, and complete a success skills program, as well as attend classes with their cohort. Requiring these activities creates a unique cohort that can be compared to students participating/not participating in other cohort programs. This assessment research will lead to better understanding the value of support services and clearer indications of how to best use these programs to support engineering students at UTA and elsewhere.

The program objectives were:

1. Increase educational opportunities for financially needy undergraduate engineering Students, with emphasis on those from typically underrepresented groups (females, ethnic minorities and persons with disabilities).

2.. Improve retention of engineering students in the coursework leading up to the engineering Professional Programs through a combination of cohort placement and required participation in support activities.

3. Increase students' knowledge of career opportunities in industry, academia and elsewhere through actual experiences.

4. Assess the effectiveness of the required support activities as they relate to retention in engineering.

The project appears to have achieved its first objective of increasing educational opportunities for underrepresented students because the percentage of underrepresented students receiving financial assistance is greater than their overall representation within engineering; female representation in the Fall 2010 cohort appears to be the exception to this accomplishment.  The study made every effort to increase students’ knowledge of career opportunities; at this time, this particular objective does not have any direct measures of effectiveness.  However, anecdotal student responses and interactions indicate project success for this objective as well.  The second and fourth research objectives center on retention.  As stated earlier, the FORCES program shows some significant impacts both in overall retention to the professional program (third year of study) across all cohorts and graduation rates for a particular cohort.  While these gains appear promising, they require further investigation to identify and evaluate the factors that help some cohorts perform better than others.  The overall retention in the third year does not appear to have fully translated into significantly greater overall graduation rates, which makes further investigation into the causes of this phenomenon critical.
